summary: Ok but like... why did Jon Snow die? What significance was Jon’s death to the story of his character?
question: Ok but like... why did Jon Snow die? What significance was Jon’s death to the story of his character?
answer:
Jon dies because he’s murdered by his fellow Night’s Watch brothers. In ADWD, Jon finds out that Ramsay Bolton has his sister Arya and intends to marry her for her claim to Winterfell. Jon breaks his vows to save Arya from this marriage and is murdered as a result.

The significance to his death is: (a) Jon is now freed of his vows and can take part in the politics of the realm now [this is key considering that he’s the rightful heir to the Iron Throne], (b) Jon will be resurrected by R’hllor, which is going to be significant with the magic necessary for the Long Night and the prophecy of Azor Ahai, © Jon will finally have “killed the boy” and “let the man be born.”

reblog.comment:

tags: oh she's so strong way too strong for him
the more crap I sift through on Youtube to remind me
what the hell happened to these characters
Jon was in no way shape or form unable to handle Dany's haughtyness
then in S8 he becomes a Jello pudding pop
with a battery pack on the stick
repeating the same damned two lines
summary:
dracke replied to your post:
                    She’s too strong for him?                
    Thing is- nothinf the characters...
body:
dracke replied to your post: She’s too strong for him?
Thing is- nothinf the characters said in s8 makes sense… it was not proved by events in other seasons. It was all a big retcon. Like “jon bent the knee to save the north” lol.WHAT? Bitch that s not what happened. It was all a big fat gaslighting.

I know!!  OMG, and I found another one:

~~~also, in S7, when people made sense~~~

Jon: Im out of here.

Dany: I haven’t given you permission to leave.

Jon: I don’t need your permission, I AM a KING, so you can cartwheel right off this cliff with your nice hair and your petite size that I find quite adorable.

Dany: *heart eyes*

tags: a song of ice and fire
title: Jon 1
body:
Jon’s POV starts with us feeling sad from him in the first line where he talks about how it is one of the few times he glad that he was a bastard. Because of Jon’s status, he doesn’t sit with the rest of his family. He sets up the atmosphere of the feast. 

Jon is a perfect character to bridge the gap between the nobles and common folk. He is the son of a lord so we get a glimpse of the lives of a noble family but his status as a bastard means he has to sit with the common folk.

Jon tries to find a positive side of his situation. We get an impression of the royal family from a different perspective. Cersei, a jeweled up beautiful queen with a fake, insincere smile. Robert, a disappointment who doesn’t match up to Ned’s stories. Myrcella, s shy, timid, insipid 8 years old. Tommen, a plump child with long hair. Joffery, a 12-year old who despite being younger than Jon and Robb is taller than them with blond curls and green eyes but Jon doesn’t like Joffery’s pouty lips or the way who looked at Winterfell. Jon then describes Jamie Lannister who despite being a Kingslayer is admired by Jon as he describes Jamie to be what a king should look like. Tyrion is the dwarf described by Jon to be ugly with mismatched eyes but fascinated Jon.  

We also get a glimpse of Jon’s relationship with his family. Ned is his father. Catelyn is referred to a Lady Stark indicating distance. Rickon as an innocent 3-year-old wants to greet Jon but is urged on by Jon who knows better. Robb, a brother whom he loves but is bitter towards. Arya is his half-sister. Sansa is his half-sister whom he describes as radiant. Uncle Benjen of Night Watch is described with affection. Theon Greyjoy and Jon seem to have some rift. 

We are again given a glimpse of the difference between Jon and his half-siblings. His half-siblings weren’t allowed to bring their pups but no one cared if Jon brought his pup so he feeds his pup under the table. We again see Jon’s struggle to find something positive out of his status. 

Ghost his pup is a symbolism of Jon. A bitch underestimates Ghost because of his size but Ghost manages to stand strong against her. 

We meet Benjen, Ned’s brother Benjen and Jon share a warm relationship. The difference between Ghost and the other pups is again a representation of the difference between Jon and the other Stark kids. They talk about Lady Stark not wanting Jon to sit with his siblings because it might be seen as an insult to the royal family. We get to see Jon’s observant side when he notices Ned’s unhappiness, Robert’s overindulgence, and Cersei’s coldness and anger.

Jon wants to join Benjen at the Wall but Benjen wants him to rethink it. Jon tries to convince him by telling that Bastards grow older faster and citing Daeron Targaryen conquering Dorne when he was 14. Benjen then points out that Daeron lost thousands of men and died when he was 18.

No character is perfect. While we fell sad for Jon and see a lot of his positive attributes he is still a child and very naive. He can see the glory in Daeron’s victory but he doesn’t see the losses and negative aspects. 

We see this has been something Jon has thought a lot about. He feels unsure about his future. They continue to debate and it ends with Jon proclaiming: 

“I will never father a bastard,” he said carefully. “Never!” He spat it out like venom.

Jon feels embarrassed by the attention and tries to leave, bringing more attention because of his drunkenness. Jon with Ghost meets Tyrion at the yard. They talk about Ghost. Ghost is a fierce but loyal and trained pup. When Jon is called a bastard by Tyrion he gets upset. We get to see that Jon has some pride over looking more northerner compared to his brothers despite being a bastard. Tyrion tries to teach Jon a valuable lesson. 

“Never forget what you are, for surely the world will not. Make it your strength. Then it can never be your weakness. Armor yourself in it, and it will never be used to hurt you.”

We learn that Tyrion is mistreated by his father. “All dwarfs are bastards in their father’s eyes.”

We also learn that Jon doesn’t know who his mother is. 

And with that he turned and sauntered back into the feast, whistling a tune. When he opened the door, the light from within threw his shadow clear across the yard, and for just a moment Tyrion Lannister stood tall as a king.

Rickon as an innocent 3-year-old wants to greet Jon but is urged on by Jon who knows better. Robb, a brother whom he loves but is bitter towards. Arya is his half-sister. Sansa is his half-sister whom he describes as radiant. Uncle Benjen of Night Watch is described with affection. Theon Greyjoy and Jon seem to have some rift. 

We are again given a glimpse of the difference between Jon and his half-siblings. His half-siblings weren’t allowed to bring their pups but no one cared if Jon brought his pup so he feeds his pup under the table. We again see Jon’s struggle to find something positive out of his status. 

Ghost his pup is a symbolism of Jon. A bitch underestimates Ghost because of his size but Ghost manages to stand strong against her. 

We meet Benjen, Ned’s brother Benjen and Jon share a warm relationship. The difference between Ghost and the other pups is again a representation of the difference between Jon and the other Stark kids. They talk about Lady Stark not wanting Jon to sit with his siblings because it might be seen as an insult to the royal family. We get to see Jon’s observant side when he notices Ned’s unhappiness, Robert’s overindulgence, and Cersei’s coldness and anger.

Jon wants to join Benjen at the Wall but Benjen wants him to rethink it. Jon tries to convince him by telling that Bastards grow older faster and citing Daeron Targaryen conquering Dorne when he was 14. Benjen then points out that Daeron lost thousands of men and died when he was 18.

No character is perfect. While we fell sad for Jon and see a lot of his positive attributes he is still a child and very naive. He can see the glory in Daeron’s victory but he doesn’t see the losses and negative aspects. 

We see this has been something Jon has thought a lot about. He feels unsure about his future. They continue to debate and it ends with Jon proclaiming: 

“I will never father a bastard,” he said carefully. “Never!” He spat it out like venom.

Jon feels embarrassed by the attention and tries to leave, bringing more attention because of his drunkenness. Jon with Ghost meets Tyrion at the yard. They talk about Ghost. Ghost is a fierce but loyal and trained pup. When Jon is called a bastard by Tyrion he gets upset. We get to see that Jon has some pride over looking more northerner compared to his brothers despite being a bastard. Tyrion tries to teach Jon a valuable lesson. 

“Never forget what you are, for surely the world will not. Make it your strength. Then it can never be your weakness. Armor yourself in it, and it will never be used to hurt you.”

We learn that Tyrion is mistreated by his father. “All dwarfs are bastards in their father’s eyes.”

We also learn that Jon doesn’t know who his mother is. 

And with that he turned and sauntered back into the feast, whistling a tune. When he opened the door, the light from within threw his shadow clear across the yard, and for just a moment Tyrion Lannister stood tall as a king.
trail.content:
Jon’s POV starts with us feeling sad from him in the first line where he talks about how it is one of the few times he glad that he was a bastard. Because of Jon’s status, he doesn’t sit with the rest of his family. He sets up the atmosphere of the feast. 

Jon is a perfect character to bridge the gap between the nobles and common folk. He is the son of a lord so we get a glimpse of the lives of a noble family but his status as a bastard means he has to sit with the common folk.

Jon tries to find a positive side of his situation. We get an impression of the royal family from a different perspective. Cersei, a jeweled up beautiful queen with a fake, insincere smile. Robert, a disappointment who doesn’t match up to Ned’s stories. Myrcella, s shy, timid, insipid 8 years old. Tommen, a plump child with long hair. Joffery, a 12-year old who despite being younger than Jon and Robb is taller than them with blond curls and green eyes but Jon doesn’t like Joffery’s pouty lips or the way who looked at Winterfell. Jon then describes Jamie Lannister who despite being a Kingslayer is admired by Jon as he describes Jamie to be what a king should look like. Tyrion is the dwarf described by Jon to be ugly with mismatched eyes but fascinated Jon.  

We also get a glimpse of Jon’s relationship with his family. Ned is his father. Catelyn is referred to a Lady Stark indicating distance. Rickon as an innocent 3-year-old wants to greet Jon but is urged on by Jon who knows better. Robb, a brother whom he loves but is bitter towards. Arya is his half-sister. Sansa is his half-sister whom he describes as radiant. Uncle Benjen of Night Watch is described with affection. Theon Greyjoy and Jon seem to have some rift. 

We are again given a glimpse of the difference between Jon and his half-siblings. His half-siblings weren’t allowed to bring their pups but no one cared if Jon brought his pup so he feeds his pup under the table. We again see Jon’s struggle to find something positive out of his status. 

Ghost his pup is a symbolism of Jon. A bitch underestimates Ghost because of his size but Ghost manages to stand strong against her. 

We meet Benjen, Ned’s brother Benjen and Jon share a warm relationship. The difference between Ghost and the other pups is again a representation of the difference between Jon and the other Stark kids. They talk about Lady Stark not wanting Jon to sit with his siblings because it might be seen as an insult to the royal family. We get to see Jon’s observant side when he notices Ned’s unhappiness, Robert’s overindulgence, and Cersei’s coldness and anger.

Jon wants to join Benjen at the Wall but Benjen wants him to rethink it. Jon tries to convince him by telling that Bastards grow older faster and citing Daeron Targaryen conquering Dorne when he was 14. Benjen then points out that Daeron lost thousands of men and died when he was 18.

No character is perfect. While we fell sad for Jon and see a lot of his positive attributes he is still a child and very naive. He can see the glory in Daeron’s victory but he doesn’t see the losses and negative aspects. 

We see this has been something Jon has thought a lot about. He feels unsure about his future. They continue to debate and it ends with Jon proclaiming: 

“I will never father a bastard,” he said carefully. “Never!” He spat it out like venom.

Jon feels embarrassed by the attention and tries to leave, bringing more attention because of his drunkenness. Jon with Ghost meets Tyrion at the yard. They talk about Ghost. Ghost is a fierce but loyal and trained pup. When Jon is called a bastard by Tyrion he gets upset. We get to see that Jon has some pride over looking more northerner compared to his brothers despite being a bastard. Tyrion tries to teach Jon a valuable lesson. 

“Never forget what you are, for surely the world will not. Make it your strength. Then it can never be your weakness. Armor yourself in it, and it will never be used to hurt you.”

We learn that Tyrion is mistreated by his father. “All dwarfs are bastards in their father’s eyes.”

We also learn that Jon doesn’t know who his mother is. 

And with that he turned and sauntered back into the feast, whistling a tune. When he opened the door, the light from within threw his shadow clear across the yard, and for just a moment Tyrion Lannister stood tall as a king.

blog.name: daynap
blog.title: Dayna Peck
blog.description: This is my blog. I don't have a theme. I reblog shit that I like.

title: Breaking the Wheel - Winterfell
excerpt: Read Winterfell from the story Breaking the Wheel by pureimagination95 with 7 reads. jamielannister, asongoficeandfire...
description:
Because I am trash, but trash that despised the GoT finale, I’m re-writing the last season in a way that I think would have served the series better. This is of course in the mindset of the TV show. I would never disrespect GRRM by believing I can write a better ending than him. But I DEFINITELY think I could write a better one than D&D did.

I felt like most, if not all, of the characters acted OOC for the final season. So, I want to give myself some closure after watching them mishandle almost EVERY SINGLE GODDAMN STORYLINE & DISRESPECTING ALMOST EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER.

It’s going to start with a similar plot as what they gave us, albeit one where the characters actually react the way I think they would to the situations they put them in, but I promise that from there my ending will be VERY DIFFERENT.

Enjoy some fan fiction-y goodness!

blog.name: shirareads
blog.description: Dogs, books, makeup, music, GOT and other stuff

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
title: Three-Headed Dragon Prophecy
body:
We know the dragon has three heads refers to Aegon, Visenya and Rhaenys.

Rhaegar was obsessed with the prophecy. He named his two kids with Elia Martell Aegon and Rhaegar. He believed the woman he was in love with (Lyanna Stark) will birth the child to fulfill the prophecy. My question is: Isn’t the third child should be a girl to fulfill the prophecy and he would name her Visenya? If Rhaegar was still alive and saw he has a boy (Jon Snow) does that mean he failed (in his eyes) to fulfill the prophecy?

summary: I feel like the a lot of the youths in asoiaf are a bit too mature and/or intelligent for their ages (regardless of life...
question: I feel like the a lot of the youths in asoiaf are a bit too mature and/or intelligent for their ages (regardless of life experiences). Could you name a few characters that you feel has an accurate depiction regarding their age and mentality + actions?
answer:
I get where you’re coming from, Anon, and I agree to some extent. However, the only POV that really feels way too old to me is Bran’s. GRRM has said that he has trouble with Bran’s POV the most because it’s hard to write from the mind of someone that young, and yeah, it shows in his writing sometimes. Even with Bran, though, there are plenty of times when Bran sounds age appropriate (Like “Why would anyone kill Jory?” or “He sent sweets to Hodor and Old Nan as well, for no reason but he loved them.”)

But, you asked for examples, so here’s my thoughts on it:

Jon’s POV is age appropriate, to an extent. At the start of his story, he’s an angsty, bratty teen with a good heart, and reads like it, for the most part.

I think Sansa and Arya start off acting their age, for sure. Sansa’s romanticism in the beginning of her arc is age appropriate, and written accordingly. I love that Arya calls everything and everyone “stupid,” and Sansa refers to her stomach as her “tummy.” Language like that definitely shows their age. Also, Sansa and Arya’s sisterly beef with each other is written perfectly, considering their ages.

However, after Sansa goes through her trauma and has grown accustomed to being a prisoner, her POV matures in a way that, while fascinating to read, still feels a bit too “old” sometimes in my opinion, if that makes sense. Like, she’s just 13, but she tends to sound like someone in their later teens, and though that doesn’t sound like a huge difference, the mind of someone who’s 17-19 is far different from someone who just turned 13. I get why GRRM would do that, because trauma can definitely age a child, and it’s beautiful writing, but I think sometimes it’s just too old in how it reads. IIRC, though (correct me if I’m wrong, I’m not a Sansa expert), she still calls her stomach her “tummy,” so there’s that. That word is associated with youth and innocence, so when Sansa starts saying “stomach” or “belly” more than “tummy” … I think it’ll be kinda sad, because it will represent more of her lost/stolen innocence, due to her trauma.

I think George does a better job with making Arya still sound childish, even after she’s traumatized. The way she thinks of her lost identity (“had she dreamed Arya Stark?”) gets the job done as far as storytelling and characterization goes, while saying it in a “childish” way.

Dany’s POV is weird. Sometimes she sounds young — maybe not as young as 13, but considering her backstory, she’s been forced to grow up long before the Stark children, so that makes sense. I think if her story started when she was 15 instead of 13, it would sound more “right,” but honestly, with the whole dramatically written crush over Daario and the mistakes she makes as a ruler, I think you can tell that she’s a teenager.

I think Theon’s POV is age appropriate. He’s college age, and acts like a particularly douchey frat boy. And when the Reek thing happens, he’s old enough that the change in prose doesn’t sound awkward. It’s all written perfectly.

Also, if non-POV characters count, Tommen and Sweetrobin act pretty age appropriate. Myrcella feels like an intelligent child. I don’t know, I think GRRM does a good job on this for the most part.

Dany’s POV is weird. Sometimes she sounds young — maybe not as young as 13, but considering her backstory, she’s been forced to grow up long before the Stark children, so that makes sense. I think if her story started when she was 15 instead of 13, it would sound more “right,” but honestly, with the whole dramatically written crush over Daario and the mistakes she makes as a ruler, I think you can tell that she’s a teenager.

I think Theon’s POV is age appropriate. He’s college age, and acts like a particularly douchey frat boy. And when the Reek thing happens, he’s old enough that the change in prose doesn’t sound awkward. It’s all written perfectly.

Also, if non-POV characters count, Tommen and Sweetrobin act pretty age appropriate. Myrcella feels like an intelligent child. I don’t know, I think GRRM does a good job on this for the most part.
